name: Axiom of Pairing
formal_statement: $\forall a \forall b \exists A \forall x (x \in A \leftrightarrow x = a \lor x = b)$
informal_description: For any two objects a and b, there exists a set that contains exactly those two objects (and nothing else). This allows us to form pairs, and by extension, finite sets.

examples.explanation: A set containing exactly the numbers 2 and 5
When both elements are the same, we get a singleton set
Sets can themselves be elements of pairs

counterexamples.formal: $\{1, 2, 3\}$ cannot be formed directly by pairing
counterexamples.explanation: The pairing axiom only guarantees sets with at most 2 distinct elements

historical_context: Part of Zermelo's original 1908 axiomatization. Essential for building finite mathematics from infinite set theory. Enables construction of natural numbers using von Neumann ordinals.
pedagogical_notes: Seems trivial but crucial for foundations. Key insight: we can build all finite sets by repeatedly applying pairing and union. When a=b, we get singleton {a}.

proof_sketches.description: Building larger finite sets from pairs
steps: Start with elements a, b, c
Use union axiom to get {a, b} âˆª {c} = {a, b, c}
Repeat process for any finite collection

applications: Building finite data structures in programming
Graph theory (edges as pairs of vertices)

relationships.description: Uniqueness of the pair follows from extensionality
Ordered pairs constructed using unordered pairs
Finite sets built by repeatedly applying pairing and union
